stage.name: Mark Item As Completed
stage.narrative: Marks the queue item as complete. May also update the item status and apply a tag.

stage.name: Mark Item As Exception
stage.narrative: Marks the item as an exception, and uses the exception type to update the status and apply a tag. Depending on the nature of the exception, this page may also make settings to restart applications or stop the process.

stage.name: Previous Exception Detail
stage.narrative: Used to store the exception marked on the previous queue item

stage.name: Consecutive Exception Count
stage.narrative: Used to count the number of times the current exception has occurred on consecutive queue items.

exception.detail: [Consecutive Exception Limit] & " consecutive incidents of " & [Exception Type] & ": " & [Exception Detail]

stage.name: Consecutive exceptions are occuring
stage.narrative: The consecutive exception limit has been reached, so throw a new exception to terminate the process.

stage.name: Mark Completed
stage.narrative: Marks the item as completed, by updating the Completed timestamp and setting Locked to null. The item must be 'owned' by the calling process - i.e. it must have been retrieved using Get Next Item.

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to mark

stage.name: Set Status
stage.narrative:
Updates the status field for the item. The status field can be used to flag what has been done in a process so far. If a process encounters an exception, this information can be used to skip to the parts of the process not yet done for the item next time it is worked. The item must be 'owned' by the calling process - i.e. it must have been retrieved using Get Next Item.
This action will also reset the Attempts column to zero, because if the status updated the process should have successfully done something.

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to mark

input.name: Status
input.narrative: The new status - 255 characters maximum.

stage.name: Retry Item ID
stage.narrative: If 'mark exception' yeilds a cloned 'retry' item, this data item will contain the item ID.

stage.name: Validate Item
stage.narrative: Used to apply preliminary validation checks to an item immediately after getting it from the queue. If a rule dictates a case cannot or should not be worked, an exception is thrown to invalidate the item.

stage.name: Start Up
stage.narrative: Sets up any global values specific to the running environment (Dev/Test/Live), checks for any potential environental problems, and then logs into the applications.

stage.name: Close Down
stage.narrative: Closes down applications and performs any other finalisation tasks.

stage.name: Note1
stage.narrative: Breakpoint

stage.name: Note1
stage.narrative: Breakpoint

stage.name: Note1
stage.narrative: Breakpoint

stage.name: Note5
stage.narrative: This choice is not essential but can be useful for adding a breakpoint on the path of a particular scenario.

stage.name: Note1
stage.narrative: Breakpoint

stage.name: Mark Item As Deferred
stage.narrative: Calculates a deferral date and returns the item to the queue. May also update the item status and apply a tag.

stage.name: Get Next Item
stage.narrative: Fetches the next item from the work queue. Often a simple 'Get Next Item' is all that is required, but any more complex selection logic (eg using different tag filters) can be placed here.

stage.name: Get Next Item
stage.narrative:
This action gets the next item to be worked from the queue, returning its details and locking it so no other case can work it.
Items with higher priorities (lower numerical value) are processed first. Where the priority is the same, the next item is the one that has been in the queue the longest, is not already locked, and is not already completed.
The Item ID returned is used to make further calls to update the work status for that item. It may be empty, in which case there are no items available. This can mean either a) the queue is empty, or b) the queue is not running. This mechanism can be used to cleanly stop all processes working a particular queue at the end of the next case. Items that have a 'deferred' time set will not be returned unless that time has been reached.

input.name: Queue Name
input.narrative: The name of the queue

input.name: Key Filter
input.narrative: Optionally, a key value to filter by. Only items with this key value will be considered.

input.name: Tag Filter
input.narrative: Optionally, a tag mask to filter by. This can consist of any number of tag searches - each term can be separated by a semi-colon and they are all applied to the search (ie. they are AND'ed terms not OR'ed terms). For example, "Account: Joint; -Balance: Overdrawn; Card: *Visa*" will include any items which match all the terms, ie. every item must have an 'Account: Joint' tag applied, no item can have a 'Balance: Overdrawn' tag applied, every item must have a tag applied which starts with 'Card: ' and then contains the text 'Visa'.

output.name: Item ID
output.narrative: The ID of the item retrieved - empty if there are none available.

output.name: Data
output.narrative: The data associated with the item - a single collection row.

output.name: Attempts
output.narrative: The number of attempts already made to work this item.

stage.name: Notify Termination
stage.narrative: Issues notification that the process is about to stop unexpectedly.

stage.name: Reset Global Data
stage.narrative: When this page runs, all its data items will be reset to their initial values.

stage.name: Exception Type
stage.narrative: Used to store the result of the ExceptionType() function for use when not in Recovery Mode.

stage.name: Exception Detail
stage.narrative: Used to store the result of the ExceptionDetail() function for use when not in Recovery Mode.

stage.name: Notify Restart
stage.narrative: Issues notification that the process is about to restart an application.

stage.name: Load Queue
stage.narrative: Loads new cases into a work queue.

stage.name: Defer Item
stage.narrative:
Marks the item as deferred. It is unlocked, but it will not be made available for processing again until the specified time.
The attempts count for the item is reset to zero.

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to defer

input.name: Until
input.narrative: When to resume processing the case

stage.name: Defer Period
stage.narrative: Used to apply a deferral to a queue item

stage.name: Maintain Queue
stage.narrative: Maintains the queue by deleting old items that have exceeded the current 'lifespan' threshold.

stage.name: Get Completed Items
stage.narrative: Gets the work items from the specified queue which have been marked as complete

input.name: Queue Name
input.narrative: The name of the queue to retrieve the completed items from

input.name: Start Date
input.narrative: The start date from which any items marked as complete should be returned. Optional - No date indicates no start date threshold

input.name: End Date
input.narrative: The end date up to which any items marked as complete should be returned. Optional - No date indicates no end date threshold

input.name: Maximum Rows
input.narrative: The maximum number of rows to return. Optional - No value indicates that all rows should be returned

input.name: Key Filter
input.narrative: Optionally, a key value to filter by. Only items with this key value will be considered.

input.name: Tag Filter
input.narrative: Optionally, a tag mask to filter by. This can consist of any number of tag searches - each term can be separated by a semi-colon and they are all applied to the search (ie. they are AND'ed terms not OR'ed terms). For example, "Account: Joint; -Balance: Overdrawn; Card: *Visa*" will include any items which match all the terms, ie. every item must have an 'Account: Joint' tag applied, no item can have a 'Balance: Overdrawn' tag applied, every item must have a tag applied which starts with 'Card: ' and then contains the text 'Visa'.

output.name: Completed Items
output.narrative: The items which were marked as complete within the given date range, up to the maximum count if one was given

field.name: Item ID
field.description: The Item ID of the work queue item

stage.name: Delete Item
stage.narrative: Delete the given item from a queue. Note that there is no locking involved in this, i.e. you should only delete an item if you are sure it is safe to do so. On the other hand, attempting to delete an item that is locked (e.g. being worked by another process) will result in an error

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to delete. An error will be raised if this item does not exist, or is locked.

stage.name: Get Exception Items
stage.narrative: Gets the work items from the specified queue which have been marked with an exception

input.name: Queue Name
input.narrative: The name of the queue to retrieve the exception items from

input.name: Start Date
input.narrative: Optionally, the start threshold date. Any items returned will have been marked as an exception after this date. If no value is given, there will be no start threshold.

input.name: End Date
input.narrative: Optionally, the end threshold date. Any items returned will have been marked as an exception before this date. If no value is given, there will be no end threshold.

input.name: Maximum Rows
input.narrative: Optionally, the maximum number of rows to return. No value indicates that all rows should be returned

input.name: Key Filter
input.narrative: Optionally, a key value to filter by. Only items with this key value will be considered.

input.name: Tag Filter
input.narrative: Optionally, a tag mask to filter by. This can consist of any number of tag searches - each term can be separated by a semi-colon and they are all applied to the search (ie. they are AND'ed terms not OR'ed terms). For example, "Account: Joint; -Balance: Overdrawn; Card: *Visa*" will include any items which match all the terms, ie. every item must have an 'Account: Joint' tag applied, no item can have a 'Balance: Overdrawn' tag applied, every item must have a tag applied which starts with 'Card: ' and then contains the text 'Visa'.

output.name: Exception Items
output.narrative: The items which were marked with an exception within the given date range, up to the maximum count if one was given

stage.name: Delete Item
stage.narrative: Delete the given item from a queue. Note that there is no locking involved in this, i.e. you should only delete an item if you are sure it is safe to do so. On the other hand, attempting to delete an item that is locked (e.g. being worked by another process) will result in an error

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to delete. An error will be raised if this item does not exist, or is locked.

stage.name: Email Item Data
stage.narrative: Used to hold email message details

calculation.expression: "The "&[Process Name]&" process is restarting "&[Application Name]&" on "&GetResourceName()&". The following exception occurred."&Chr(10) &Chr(10)&"Exception Type: "&[Exception Type] &Chr(10)&"Exception Detail: "&[Exception Detail]

stage.name: Control Applications
stage.narrative:
Maintains target applications by starting, restarting, closing down or just keeping a session from timing out.
When not working a queue item this normally will mean returning an application back to it's 'ready' state.

stage.name: Completed Item Status
stage.narrative: Used to update the Status of a completed item, and also as an indicator that the item can be routed to the 'mark as complete' step.

stage.name: Completed Item Tag
stage.narrative: Used to apply a tag to a completed item, and also as an indicator that the item can be routed to the 'mark as complete' step.

stage.name: Tag Item
stage.narrative: Adds a tag to a work queue item

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the queue item to add the tag to

input.name: Tag
input.narrative: The tag to add to the item. Note that this cannot start with a '+' (plus) or '-' (minus) character, and cannot contain ';' (semi-colon) characters

stage.name: Set Status
stage.narrative:
Updates the status field for the item. The status field can be used to flag what has been done in a process so far. If a process encounters an exception, this information can be used to skip to the parts of the process not yet done for the item next time it is worked. The item must be 'owned' by the calling process - i.e. it must have been retrieved using Get Next Item.
This action will also reset the Attempts column to zero, because if the status updated the process should have successfully done something.

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to mark

input.name: Status
input.narrative: The new status - 255 characters maximum.

stage.name: Deferred Item Status
stage.narrative: Used to update the Status of a completed item, and also as an indicator that the item can be routed to the 'defer' step.

stage.name: Deferred Item Tag
stage.narrative: Used to apply a tag to a completed item, and also as an indicator that the item can be routed to the 'defer' step.

stage.name: Tag Item
stage.narrative: Adds a tag to a work queue item

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the queue item to add the tag to

input.name: Tag
input.narrative: The tag to add to the item. Note that this cannot start with a '+' (plus) or '-' (minus) character, and cannot contain ';' (semi-colon) characters

stage.name: Mark Exception
stage.narrative: Marks the item as an exception, optionally retrying it by cloning the item and returning the ID of the clone. The item must be 'owned' by the calling process - i.e. it must have been retrieved using Get Next Item.

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to mark

input.name: Exception Reason
input.narrative: A description of the reason for the exception

input.name: Retry
input.narrative: Whether or not to retry the item, up to the maximum number of attempts specified for the queue. Optional - if not specified, the item will be retried

input.name: Keep Locked
input.narrative: Whether or not the clone of the item should remain locked after the exception has been registered and the item is retried. Optional - default is False

output.name: New Item ID
output.narrative: The Item ID of the newly cloned item. This item will be locked if 'Keep Locked' is True. This will be empty if no item was cloned (ie. the item was not retried.

stage.name: Mark Exception
stage.narrative: Marks the item as an exception, optionally retrying it by cloning the item and returning the ID of the clone. The item must be 'owned' by the calling process - i.e. it must have been retrieved using Get Next Item.

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to mark

input.name: Exception Reason
input.narrative: A description of the reason for the exception

input.name: Retry
input.narrative: Whether or not to retry the item, up to the maximum number of attempts specified for the queue. Optional - if not specified, the item will be retried

input.name: Keep Locked
input.narrative: Whether or not the clone of the item should remain locked after the exception has been registered and the item is retried. Optional - default is False

output.name: New Item ID
output.narrative: The Item ID of the newly cloned item. This item will be locked if 'Keep Locked' is True. This will be empty if no item was cloned (ie. the item was not retried.

stage.name: Defer
stage.narrative:
Marks the item as deferred. It is unlocked, but it will not be made available for processing again until the specified time.
The attempts count for the item is reset to zero.

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the item to defer

input.name: Until
input.narrative: When to resume processing the case

stage.name: Note5
stage.narrative: The queue has cloned a new item to retry. Rather than work it immediately, return it to the queue as deferred.

stage.name: Note5
stage.narrative: Don't retry this type of exception, just mark the queue item and carry on.

stage.name: Note5
stage.narrative: This exception is different from the previous one.

stage.name: Note5
stage.narrative: This exception is the same as the previous one but the consecutive exception limit has not yet been reached.

stage.name: Get Lock
stage.narrative: Acquires the lock associated with the given name. If this session already holds the required lock, it will be re-acquired with a new token

input.name: Name
input.narrative: The name of the required lock. Mandatory parameter.

input.name: Timeout
input.narrative: The maximum amount of time to await the lock. Default is to wait forever

input.name: Preferred Token
input.narrative: The preferred token to use for the lock. Default behaviour is to generate a new unique token.

input.name: Comment
input.narrative: The comments to set on the lock

output.name: Token
output.narrative: The token registered against the lock. This will be empty if the lock could not be acquired

stage.name: Note5
stage.narrative: Someone else probably has the lock, so avoid this section.

stage.name: Release Lock
stage.narrative: Releases the lock(s) associated with the given name and token

input.name: Name
input.narrative: The name of the specific lock to be released. Default behaviour is to release all locks with the given token.

input.name: Comment
input.narrative: The comments to set on the lock(s)

input.name: Token
input.narrative: The token associated with the lock(s) to be released. Mandatory parameter.

input.name: All Sessions
input.narrative: True to release locks matching the specified constraints across all sessions; False to only release locks acquired in the current session. Default is False

stage.name: Release Lock
stage.narrative: Releases the lock(s) associated with the given name and token

input.name: Name
input.narrative: The name of the specific lock to be released. Default behaviour is to release all locks with the given token.

input.name: Comment
input.narrative: The comments to set on the lock(s)

input.name: Token
input.narrative: The token associated with the lock(s) to be released. Mandatory parameter.

input.name: All Sessions
input.narrative: True to release locks matching the specified constraints across all sessions; False to only release locks acquired in the current session. Default is False

stage.name: Unpack Item
stage.narrative: Used if the data in a queue item contains 'raw' data that must be manipulated (eg cast) before work commences.

stage.name: Wait Interval
stage.narrative: The number of seconds to wait between restart attempts.

stage.name: Poll
stage.narrative: Waits for new work to arrive, with the option of closing down applications.

stage.name: Note2
stage.narrative: ** In this example a date supplied as Text is cast into a Date data item. In case the cast fails, exception handling is used and a new exception containing a friendly message is thrown.

stage.name: Validate Environment
stage.narrative: Checks any environmental settings the process requires, eg screen resolution, folder access etc (the 'environment' and 'file' utility business objects could be useful here).

stage.name: Note2
stage.narrative: ** Add/remove as required

stage.name: Note2
stage.narrative: ** Modify input parameter

stage.name: Queue Lifespan
stage.narrative: Used to determine the threshold date for deleting old queue items.

stage.name: Note2
stage.narrative: ** This example assumes the 'Exit System' pages will not fail if the applications are already closed down, and likewise the 'Start System' pages will not fail if the applications are already running.

stage.name: Note2
stage.narrative: ** In this example a global flag is set to indicate whether any work was loaded into the queue.

decision.expression: [Stop After Failure To Control Applications] OR [Stop ASAP] OR [Stop After Items]=1 OR LocalTime()>[Stop After Time]

stage.name: Note8
stage.narrative: Keep trying to restart

decision.expression: Trim(Upper([CONTROL App ABC]))<>"RESTART" AND Trim(Upper([CONTROL App ABC]))<>"START" AND Trim(Upper([CONTROL App ABC]))<>"EXIT"

stage.name: Note11
stage.narrative: Reset App ABC and keep session alive

stage.name: Note10
stage.narrative: Must be Start

decision.expression: [Stop After Failure To Control Applications] OR [Stop ASAP] OR [Stop After Items]=1 OR LocalTime()>[Stop After Time]

stage.name: Note8

stage.name: CONTROL App ABC
stage.narrative: Used to instruct to the Control Applications page to affect an application. The available instructions are START, RESTART and EXIT. The default value (blank) indicates that the application should simply be maintained/returned to the 'ready' position/kept alive.

stage.name: CONTROL App XYZ
stage.narrative: Used to instruct to the Control Applications page to affect an application. The available instructions are START, RESTART and EXIT. The default value (blank) indicates that the application should simply be maintained/returned to the 'ready' position/kept alive.

stage.name: Tag Item
stage.narrative: Adds a tag to a work queue item

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the queue item to add the tag to

input.name: Tag
input.narrative: The tag to add to the item. Note that this cannot start with a '+' (plus) or '-' (minus) character, and cannot contain ';' (semi-colon) characters

stage.name: Tag Item
stage.narrative: Adds a tag to a work queue item

input.name: Item ID
input.narrative: The ID of the queue item to add the tag to

decision.expression: [Stop ASAP] OR [Stop After Items]=0 OR LocalTime()>[Stop After Time]

stage.name: Note2
stage.narrative: ** Add/remove as required

stage.name: Note7
stage.narrative: There are no more items available

stage.name: Stop After Time
stage.narrative: Used by the process to decide whether to keep working or close itself down. This value can be modified from Control Room to bring a session to an early finish.

stage.name: Stop After Items
stage.narrative: Used by the process to decide whether to keep working or close itself down. This value can be modified from Control Room to bring a session to an early finish.

stage.name: Stop ASAP
stage.narrative: Used by the process to decide whether to keep working or close itself down. This value can be modified from Control Room to bring a session to an early finish.

stage.name: Stop After Failure To Control Applications
stage.narrative: Used by the process to decide whether to terminate if it fails to maintain an application, or whether to keep trying.
